API Reference

This section provides detailed documentation for all Odecast functions and classes.

Core Functions

Main APIs for odecast

class odecast.api.BC(variable, *, t=None, value=None)[source]

Bases: object

Boundary condition for boundary value problems (BVP).

Boundary conditions specify the value of a variable or its derivative at specific points in the domain. This is used for BVP problems where conditions are given at multiple points rather than all at the initial point.

Parameters:

  • variable – The variable or derivative to constrain (Variable or Derivative object)

  • t – The time/position where the condition applies

  • value – The required value at that position

Examples

>>> y = var("y")
>>> bc1 = BC(y, t=0, value=0)      # y(0) = 0
>>> bc2 = BC(y, t=1, value=1)      # y(1) = 1
>>> bc3 = BC(y.d(), t=0, value=0)  # y'(0) = 0

BVP problem: >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0) >>> sol = solve(eq, bvp=[bc1, bc2], tspan=(0, 1), backend=”scipy_bvp”)

Note

BVP solving is not yet implemented and will be available in future versions.

odecast.api.solve(equation, *, ivp=None, bvp=None, tspan=None, backend=None, **kwargs)[source]

Solve an ordinary differential equation or system of ODEs.

This is the main entry point for solving differential equations. It supports both symbolic and numeric solutions through different backends.

Parameters:

  • equation – Single Eq object or list of Eq objects representing the ODE system

  • ivp – Dictionary of initial conditions for initial value problems (IVP). Keys can be Variable objects (for y(t0)) or Derivative objects (for y’(t0)). Example: {y: 1.0, y.d(): 0.0} for y(0)=1, y’(0)=0

  • bvp – List of boundary conditions for boundary value problems (BVP). Currently not implemented - will be available in future versions.

  • tspan – Tuple of (t_start, t_end) for numeric solutions. Required for scipy backend, ignored for sympy backend.

  • backend – Solution backend to use: - “scipy”: Numeric integration using SciPy (default) - “sympy”: Symbolic solution using SymPy - “auto”: Try SymPy first, fall back to SciPy if needed - “scipy_bvp”: BVP solver (not yet implemented)

  • **kwargs – Additional backend-specific options: For scipy: method, rtol, atol, max_step, etc.

Returns:

  • SolutionIVP: For numeric solutions, supports sol[y], sol[y.d()], etc.

  • SolutionExpr: For symbolic solutions, supports sol.as_expr(y)

Return type:

Solution object that depends on the backend

Raises:

  • MissingInitialConditionError – When required initial conditions are missing

  • OverdeterminedConditionsError – When too many initial conditions provided

  • OrderMismatchError – When declared variable order conflicts with equation usage

  • BackendError – When the chosen backend cannot solve the equation

  • ValueError – When required arguments are missing (e.g., tspan for scipy)

Examples

Numeric solution of second-order ODE: >>> y = var(“y”) >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + 0.3*y.d() + y, 0) >>> sol = solve(eq, ivp={y: 1.0, y.d(): 0.0}, tspan=(0, 10)) >>> y_values = sol[y] # Get y(t) values >>> yprime_values = sol[y.d()] # Get y’(t) values

Symbolic solution: >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0) >>> sol = solve(eq, backend=”sympy”) >>> expr = sol.as_expr(y) # Get SymPy expression

Coupled system: >>> y, z = var(“y”), var(“z”) >>> eq1 = Eq(y.d(2) + z, 0) >>> eq2 = Eq(z.d() - y, 0) >>> sol = solve([eq1, eq2], ivp={y: 1.0, y.d(): 0.0, z: 0.0}, tspan=(0, 5))

odecast.api.var(name: str, order: int | None = None, shape: tuple | None = None) → Variable[source]

Create a dependent variable for use in differential equations.

The variable represents an unknown function y(t) where t is the independent variable. You can create derivatives using the .d(n) method.

Parameters:

  • name – Name of the variable (e.g., “y”, “x”, “theta”)

  • order – Maximum order of derivatives expected (optional, for validation). If specified and equations use higher-order derivatives, an OrderMismatchError will be raised.

  • shape – Shape tuple for vector/matrix variables (e.g., (3,) for 3D vector, (2, 2) for 2x2 matrix). None for scalar variables.

Returns:

  • Arithmetic operations: y + z, 2*y, y/3, etc.

  • Derivative notation: y.d() for y’, y.d(2) for y’’, etc.

  • Use in equations: Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0)

  • Component access for vectors: u[0], u[1] for vector components

  • Vectorized operations: u.d() + 2*u for vector equations

Return type:

Variable object that supports

Examples

>>> y = var("y")           # Create scalar variable y(t)
>>> y.d()                  # First derivative y'(t)
>>> y.d(2)                 # Second derivative y''(t)
>>> Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0)     # Simple harmonic oscillator

>>> u = var("u", shape=(2,))  # Create 2D vector variable u(t)
>>> u[0]                      # First component u[0](t)
>>> u.d()                     # Vector derivative u'(t)
>>> Eq(u.d() + u, 0)         # Vector equation u' + u = 0

>>> z = var("z", order=1)  # Declare z as first-order only
>>> Eq(z.d() - z, 0)       # Valid: uses only first derivative
>>> Eq(z.d(2) + z, 0)      # Would raise OrderMismatchError

Variables and Equations

odecast.var(name: str, order: int | None = None, shape: tuple | None = None) → Variable[source]

Create a dependent variable for use in differential equations.

The variable represents an unknown function y(t) where t is the independent variable. You can create derivatives using the .d(n) method.

Parameters:

  • name – Name of the variable (e.g., “y”, “x”, “theta”)

  • order – Maximum order of derivatives expected (optional, for validation). If specified and equations use higher-order derivatives, an OrderMismatchError will be raised.

  • shape – Shape tuple for vector/matrix variables (e.g., (3,) for 3D vector, (2, 2) for 2x2 matrix). None for scalar variables.

Returns:

  • Arithmetic operations: y + z, 2*y, y/3, etc.

  • Derivative notation: y.d() for y’, y.d(2) for y’’, etc.

  • Use in equations: Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0)

  • Component access for vectors: u[0], u[1] for vector components

  • Vectorized operations: u.d() + 2*u for vector equations

Return type:

Variable object that supports

Examples

>>> y = var("y")           # Create scalar variable y(t)
>>> y.d()                  # First derivative y'(t)
>>> y.d(2)                 # Second derivative y''(t)
>>> Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0)     # Simple harmonic oscillator

>>> u = var("u", shape=(2,))  # Create 2D vector variable u(t)
>>> u[0]                      # First component u[0](t)
>>> u.d()                     # Vector derivative u'(t)
>>> Eq(u.d() + u, 0)         # Vector equation u' + u = 0

>>> z = var("z", order=1)  # Declare z as first-order only
>>> Eq(z.d() - z, 0)       # Valid: uses only first derivative
>>> Eq(z.d(2) + z, 0)      # Would raise OrderMismatchError
odecast.Eq(lhs, rhs=0)[source]

Represents an ordinary differential equation.

The Eq class is used to create equations of the form lhs = rhs, where the left and right sides can contain variables, derivatives, and expressions. This mirrors SymPy’s Eq class but works with odecast’s Variable and Derivative objects.

Examples

Simple harmonic oscillator: >>> y = var(“y”) >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0)

Damped oscillator with forcing: >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + 0.3*y.d() + y, sp.sin(t.symbol))

First-order ODE: >>> eq = Eq(y.d() - 2*y, 0)

Coupled system: >>> y, z = var(“y”), var(“z”) >>> eq1 = Eq(y.d() - z, 0) >>> eq2 = Eq(z.d() + y, 0)

odecast.t = t

The distinguished independent variable, typically time.

Solving Functions

odecast.solve(equation, *, ivp=None, bvp=None, tspan=None, backend=None, **kwargs)[source]

Solve an ordinary differential equation or system of ODEs.

This is the main entry point for solving differential equations. It supports both symbolic and numeric solutions through different backends.

Parameters:

  • equation – Single Eq object or list of Eq objects representing the ODE system

  • ivp – Dictionary of initial conditions for initial value problems (IVP). Keys can be Variable objects (for y(t0)) or Derivative objects (for y’(t0)). Example: {y: 1.0, y.d(): 0.0} for y(0)=1, y’(0)=0

  • bvp – List of boundary conditions for boundary value problems (BVP). Currently not implemented - will be available in future versions.

  • tspan – Tuple of (t_start, t_end) for numeric solutions. Required for scipy backend, ignored for sympy backend.

  • backend – Solution backend to use: - “scipy”: Numeric integration using SciPy (default) - “sympy”: Symbolic solution using SymPy - “auto”: Try SymPy first, fall back to SciPy if needed - “scipy_bvp”: BVP solver (not yet implemented)

  • **kwargs – Additional backend-specific options: For scipy: method, rtol, atol, max_step, etc.

Returns:

  • SolutionIVP: For numeric solutions, supports sol[y], sol[y.d()], etc.

  • SolutionExpr: For symbolic solutions, supports sol.as_expr(y)

Return type:

Solution object that depends on the backend

Raises:

  • MissingInitialConditionError – When required initial conditions are missing

  • OverdeterminedConditionsError – When too many initial conditions provided

  • OrderMismatchError – When declared variable order conflicts with equation usage

  • BackendError – When the chosen backend cannot solve the equation

  • ValueError – When required arguments are missing (e.g., tspan for scipy)

Examples

Numeric solution of second-order ODE: >>> y = var(“y”) >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + 0.3*y.d() + y, 0) >>> sol = solve(eq, ivp={y: 1.0, y.d(): 0.0}, tspan=(0, 10)) >>> y_values = sol[y] # Get y(t) values >>> yprime_values = sol[y.d()] # Get y’(t) values

Symbolic solution: >>> eq = Eq(y.d(2) + y, 0) >>> sol = solve(eq, backend=”sympy”) >>> expr = sol.as_expr(y) # Get SymPy expression

Coupled system: >>> y, z = var(“y”), var(“z”) >>> eq1 = Eq(y.d(2) + z, 0) >>> eq2 = Eq(z.d() - y, 0) >>> sol = solve([eq1, eq2], ivp={y: 1.0, y.d(): 0.0, z: 0.0}, tspan=(0, 5))

Validation and Errors

Custom error types for odecast

exception odecast.errors.BackendError[source]

Bases: OdecastError

Raised when a backend-specific error occurs.

exception odecast.errors.CompilationError[source]

Bases: OdecastError

Raised when symbolic to numeric compilation fails.

exception odecast.errors.MissingInitialConditionError[source]

Bases: OdecastError

Raised when required initial conditions are missing.

exception odecast.errors.NonSolvableFormError[source]

Bases: OdecastError

Raised when the equation cannot be solved in the required form.

exception odecast.errors.OdecastError[source]

Bases: Exception

Base exception for odecast errors.

exception odecast.errors.OrderMismatchError[source]

Bases: OdecastError

Raised when variable order doesn’t match equation requirements.

exception odecast.errors.OverdeterminedConditionsError[source]

Bases: OdecastError

Raised when too many initial/boundary conditions are provided.

Internal Modules

The following modules are primarily for internal use but may be useful for advanced users or contributors.

Equation Analysis

Analysis functions for ODEs - order inference, validation, etc.

odecast.analyze.analyze_equation(equation)[source]

Analyze an equation to determine properties like order, variables involved, etc.

This is a placeholder for future implementation.

odecast.analyze.collect_variables(eqs: List[Eq]) → Set[Variable][source]

Collect all variables used in the given equations.

Parameters:

eqs – List of equations to analyze

Returns:

Set of Variable objects found in the equations

odecast.analyze.infer_orders(eqs: List[Eq]) → Dict[Variable, int][source]

Infer the maximum derivative order for each variable from the equations.

Parameters:

eqs – List of equations to analyze

Returns:

Dictionary mapping each variable to its maximum derivative order

odecast.analyze.resolve_orders(variables: List[Variable], inferred: Dict[Variable, int]) → Dict[Variable, int][source]

Resolve final orders by checking intent_order against inferred orders.

Parameters:

  • variables – List of variables to resolve orders for

  • inferred – Dictionary of inferred orders from equations

Returns:

Dictionary mapping each variable to its resolved order

Raises:

OrderMismatchError – If intent_order is set but is less than inferred order

Compilation

Compilation of symbolic expressions to numerical functions

odecast.compile.compile_to_function(expression)[source]

Compile a symbolic expression to a numerical function.

This is a placeholder that will be removed once the above functions are integrated.

odecast.compile.lambdify_jac(jac_sym: MutableDenseMatrix | None, t_symbol: Symbol, state_syms: List[Symbol], param_names: List[str] | None = None) → Callable | None[source]

Compile symbolic Jacobian matrix to a numerical function.

Parameters:

  • jac_sym – SymPy Matrix representing the Jacobian df/dx (can be None)

  • t_symbol – SymPy symbol for time

  • state_syms – List of SymPy symbols for state variables

  • param_names – Optional list of parameter names

Returns:

Callable function jac(t, x) -> np.ndarray, or None if jac_sym is None

odecast.compile.lambdify_rhs(f_sym_vec: MutableDenseMatrix, t_symbol: Symbol, state_syms: List[Symbol], param_names: List[str] | None = None) → Callable[source]

Compile symbolic RHS vector to a numerical function.

Parameters:

  • f_sym_vec – SymPy Matrix representing the RHS vector f(t, x)

  • t_symbol – SymPy symbol for time

  • state_syms – List of SymPy symbols for state variables [x0, x1, …]

  • param_names – Optional list of parameter names to include in the function

Returns:

Callable function f(t, x) -> np.ndarray

Order Reduction

Reduction of higher-order ODEs to first-order systems

class odecast.reduce.StateMapping[source]

Bases: dict

Enhanced state mapping that supports both Variable and (Variable, level) access patterns.

This class ensures that mapping[var][level] == mapping[(var, level)] for consistency across the API as required by Playbook 8.

class odecast.reduce.VariableIndexer(mapping: StateMapping, variable: Variable)[source]

Bases: object

Helper class that makes mapping[var][level] equivalent to mapping[(var, level)].

odecast.reduce.build_state_map(orders: Dict[Variable, int]) → StateMapping[source]

Build a state mapping for converting higher-order ODEs to first-order systems.

Parameters:

orders – Dictionary mapping each Variable to its maximum derivative order

Returns:

  • mapping[var][level] returns state index for derivative level

  • mapping[(var, level)] returns same state index

Return type:

StateMapping with consistent access patterns

odecast.reduce.isolate_highest_derivatives(eqs: List[Eq], orders: Dict[Variable, int]) → Dict[Variable, Expr][source]

Isolate the highest derivatives in the equations.

For each variable with order k>0, find an equation containing the k-th derivative and solve for that derivative in terms of t and lower derivatives.

Parameters:

  • eqs – List of equations

  • orders – Dictionary mapping variables to their orders

Returns:

Dictionary mapping each variable to a SymPy expression for its highest derivative

Raises:

NonSolvableFormError – If a highest derivative cannot be isolated

odecast.reduce.make_rhs(t_symbol: Symbol, mapping: Dict[Variable | tuple, List[int] | int], highest_rules: Dict[Variable, Expr], params: Dict[str, float] | None = None) → tuple[MutableDenseMatrix, MutableDenseMatrix | None][source]

Build the right-hand side vector field f(t, x) for the first-order system.

Parameters:

  • t_symbol – The SymPy symbol for the independent variable

  • mapping – State mapping from build_state_map

  • highest_rules – Expressions for highest derivatives from isolate_highest_derivatives

  • params – Optional parameter values to substitute

Returns:

Tuple of (f_sympy_vector, jac_sympy_matrix) - f_sympy_vector: SymPy Matrix representing dx/dt = f(t, x) - jac_sympy_matrix: SymPy Matrix representing the Jacobian df/dx (optional for MVP)

odecast.reduce.reduce_to_first_order(equation, initial_conditions)[source]

Reduce a higher-order ODE to a system of first-order ODEs.

This is a placeholder for future implementation that will integrate the above functions.

Validation

Validation functions for ODEs and initial/boundary conditions

Normalize IVP dictionary to use (Variable, level) keys.

Parameters:

ivp_dict – Dictionary with Variable (level 0), Derivative (level n≥1), or VectorDerivative keys, with values that can be floats or lists

Returns:

Dictionary with (Variable, level) keys for all components

odecast.validate.validate_initial_conditions(equation, conditions)[source]

Validate that initial conditions match the equation requirements.

This is a placeholder that will be removed once the above functions are integrated.

odecast.validate.validate_ivp(orders: Dict[Variable, int], ivp: Dict[Variable | Derivative, float], t0: float) → None[source]

Validate that IVP has correct number of initial conditions.

Parameters:

  • orders – Dictionary mapping variables to their orders

  • ivp – IVP dictionary with initial conditions

  • t0 – Initial time

Raises:

  • MissingInitialConditionError – When required initial conditions are missing

  • OverdeterminedConditionsError – When too many conditions are provided

odecast.validate.validate_variable_orders(equations: List[Eq], declared_orders: Dict[Variable, int]) → None[source]

Validate that declared variable orders match equation requirements.

Parameters:

  • equations – List of equations to check

  • declared_orders – Dictionary of explicitly declared variable orders

Raises:

OrderMismatchError – When declared order doesn’t match equation usage

Backend Implementations

SciPy-based backend for solving initial value problems

class odecast.backends.scipy_ivp.ScipyIVPBackend[source]

Bases: object

Backend for solving IVPs using SciPy’s solve_ivp.

solve(f_compiled: Callable, jac_compiled: Callable | None, x0: ndarray, t0: float, tspan: Tuple[float, float], mapping: Dict[Variable | Tuple[Variable, int], list | int], options: Dict[str, Any] | None = None) → SolutionIVP[source]

Solve the IVP using SciPy’s solve_ivp.

Parameters:

  • f_compiled – Compiled RHS function f(t, x) -> dx/dt

  • jac_compiled – Compiled Jacobian function (optional)

  • x0 – Initial state vector

  • t0 – Initial time

  • tspan – Tuple of (t_start, t_end)

  • mapping – State mapping from build_state_map

  • options – Additional solver options

Returns:

SolutionIVP object with results

odecast.backends.scipy_ivp.convert_ivp_to_state_vector(ivp_dict: Dict[Variable | Derivative, float], mapping: Dict[Variable | Tuple[Variable, int], list | int]) → ndarray[source]

Convert IVP dictionary to initial state vector.

Parameters:

  • ivp_dict – Dictionary mapping variables/derivatives to initial values

  • mapping – State mapping from build_state_map

Returns:

Initial state vector x0

Solve an IVP using SciPy’s solve_ivp.

This is a placeholder that will be removed once the ScipyIVPBackend is integrated.

SciPy-based backend for solving boundary value problems

class odecast.backends.scipy_bvp.ScipyBVPBackend[source]

Bases: object

Backend for solving boundary value problems using SciPy’s solve_bvp.

This backend will handle two-point boundary value problems where conditions are specified at multiple points in the domain.

solve(system: Any, bvp: List[BC], tspan: tuple, options: Dict = None) → Any[source]

Solve a boundary value problem.

Parameters:

  • system – First-order system representation

  • bvp – List of boundary conditions

  • tspan – Integration domain (start, end)

  • options – Additional solver options

Returns:

Solution object for BVP

Raises:

NotImplementedError – BVP implementation arrives in Milestone 5

odecast.backends.scipy_bvp.solve_bvp_scipy(equation, boundary_conditions, tspan, **kwargs)[source]

Solve a BVP using SciPy’s solve_bvp.

This is a placeholder for future implementation.
